instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.820-00045A: What is 820-00045A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.3V3_S4: What is 3V3_S4? This is an abbreviation of PP3V3_S4, a 3.3v power rail when the machine is in an S4 state. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
Hi Guys,

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.56V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.28V
<SIGNAL>PPVBUS_E85</SIGNAL> = 20.4V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 20.4 (logical)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.29V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> = 3.25V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3H_LDO</SIGNAL> = 4.97V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 4.99V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 4.97V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = PULSING Between 3.3 and 0

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.5V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> = 1.2V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> = 1.06V


Also i found something called a "Matt Card" on the board.. What the he** is this ?..


Guys Help me out

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
I suppose <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is steady high.
In such case, change <CHIP>U8000</CHIP>.
Just in case, test first disconnecting trackpad (J4801).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
Yep - <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> always 3.3V - so I need to change <CHIP>U8000</CHIP>?

Maybe you know the Part designation ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message: As the schematic notation, <CHIP>TPS22924</CHIP>; easy to find in many Apple scrap boards.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
which voltage did inform you about the "always high state" of this rail ?

Or better said - how did you know?
And this voltage should only be high if "on Button" is pressed?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
Only S5 power rails appear before pressing power button; when charger is connected, of course.
S4/3/0 voltages require to start the machine with power button.

As you get stable S3/0 voltages, S4 ones shouldn't pulse, must be steady high too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
So if I understand you correctly, the S4/3/0 Power Rails shouldn't be present if no button is pressed ?

And if they are, <CHIP>U8000</CHIP> could be faulty as its giving out these Lines ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message: First time when charger is connected, board should automatically turn on; no need to press power button.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
So again - Just to understand for me please..

Why isnt it okay then If S5 is present?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message: Who said that???

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 69690, member: 682"]
I suppose <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is steady high.
In such case, change <CHIP>U8000</CHIP>.
[/QUOTE]

I thought this is ment to be not to be okay

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message: S5 state MUST be achieved once charger is connected; no matters board is on, or off.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
Well.. this is the case..
World be almost impossible if S0 is there and S5 isnt right ?

So why do you think <CHIP>U8000</CHIP> is the problem ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message: Because you have stable S3/0 voltages, but pulsing S4 voltage from <CHIP>U8000</CHIP> output.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message: Thanks in advance ! Appreciate your help man ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is 2.06V not pulsing anymore.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
The other S3 and S0 voltages present?
Possibly bad solders at <CHIP>U8000</CHIP>.
Post diode mode (red probe at ground) for <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 4.98V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> -3.30V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> - 1.806V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> - 1.517V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>  - 1.056V
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 1.709V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> to Ground 0.32V
Ohms Mode on <CAPACITOR>C7830</CAPACITOR> to ground is 44.8kOhm

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
As you said - i will change <CHIP>U8000</CHIP> - ordered my Donor Board today as my last one is almost empty :D

BTW:
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> changed to 20.5V is this normal ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
Why do you bother with USB-C input, if already got S3 and S0 voltages?
20.5V is good voltage, no problem.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message: Shoudnt <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> be 3.3V

threads.message: Not at all, it is an VIN voltage!!!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
Any S3 voltage present, or pulsing at least?

Please, STOP to quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> = 1.202V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
Do not confuse turned on board with working board!
Your board turns on at least.
Check now if you get S0 voltages, especially VCORE.
If present, check for USB activity.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.29V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.516V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.054V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_SSD</SIGNAL> = 3.29V
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 1.706V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message: So VCORE is present, did you check for USB activity?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message: How should i do this if there is only one USB Port ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message: Of course, use the battery...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
The battery is not charged.. Is there a possible way to charge it outside the Mac ? Like externally ?
I think the battery is dead maybe ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message: In such case you need an USB-C hub with power port and USB 3 output.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message: Okay but this doesn't solve the problem, that the Screen still stays black right ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
You need to confirm USB activity first, to know if board boots.
No reason to search video on a turned on board, but not booted.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message:
Okay I will order such an USB Hub and inform you further :)

But if the Board Doesn't boot - what could cause such a Problem ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> "DeadCPUBook" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board doesnt turn on
threads.message: Bad CPU usually; common issue for these boards.
